title: About
text:
Hey there! I’m Niya, a passionate sports media and broadcasting student with a deep love for storytelling. I’m dedicated to uncovering the narratives that numbers tell and love using data to add depth to the conversation of sports. My background in media production and fashion merchandising also gives me a unique perspective on how sports intersect with culture, branding, and digital storytelling.
Through this blog, I share insights, breakdowns, and compelling stories from the world of sports. Whatever drew you here, I’m glad you stayed, let’s dive in!

title: The New York Liberty Three-point Success Analysis
text:
The New York Liberty Dominate Three-point Shooting.
Or at least… that’s what I thought.
Heading into this analysis, I assumed the top team in the WNBA 2024 season had to be lights-out when it came to three-point shooting. The New York Liberty racked up wins, played with confidence, and looked unstoppable—but when I created a scatter plot comparing three-point percentage to win percentage across teams, the results surprised me. The Liberty were certainly winning, but their three-point shooting? Just barely above average. This finding challenged my assumptions and raised a bigger question: If it’s not the three-points then what’s actually driving their success?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(wehoop)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

wnbadata <- load_wnba_team_box(2024) |> 
  filter(season_type == 2)

seasondata <- wnbadata |> 
  group_by(team_name) |> 
  summarize(
    total_threes_attempted = sum(three_point_field_goals_attempted),
    total_threes_made = sum(three_point_field_goals_made),
    total_wins = sum(ifelse(team_winner == TRUE, 1, 0))
  ) |> 
  mutate(total_three_point_pct = (total_threes_made/total_threes_attempted)*100) |> 
  filter(total_threes_attempted > 100)

libertyseasondata <- seasondata |>
  filter(team_name == "Liberty")

ggplot() +
geom_point(data=seasondata, aes(x=total_three_point_pct, y=total_wins)) +
  geom_point(data=libertyseasondata, aes(x=total_three_point_pct, y=total_wins), color="red") +
  labs(x="Total 3-point Percentage", y="Total Wins", title="WNBA 2024 Season 3-Point Percentage vs. Wins", subtitle= "Highlighting New York Liberty's 3-point shooting impact on wins (red dot)", caption="Source: Wehoop") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    ) +
  theme_minimal()









Well, let’s look into other factors like rebounds.
While the New York Liberty’s three-point shooting may not set them apart, another stat certainly does—rebounds. In my second chart, I looked at total rebounds versus total wins, and the Liberty emerged as the dominant team. Their ability to consistently secure rebound, both offensively and defensively, suggests that their success isn’t built solely on shooting efficiency but also on controlling possessions. Rebounding may not always make the highlight reel, but for the Liberty, it’s clearly a core ingredient in their winning formula.


Code
wnbadata <- load_wnba_team_box(2024) |> 
  filter(season_type == 2)

seasondata <- wnbadata |> 
  group_by(team_name) |> 
  summarize(
    total_rebounds = sum(total_rebounds),
    total_wins = sum(ifelse(team_winner == TRUE, 1, 0))
) |>
  filter(total_rebounds > 100)
  
libertydata <- seasondata |>
  filter(
    team_name == "Liberty"
)

ggplot(seasondata, aes(x = total_rebounds, y = total_wins)) +
  geom_point(aes(size = total_rebounds, fill = team_name == "Liberty"),
             shape = 21, color = "black", alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_size(range = c(4, 10), name = "Total Rebounds") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("none" = "grey", "TRUE" = "red"), guide = FALSE) +
  labs(x="Total rebounds", 
       y="Total wins", 
       title="Rebounding To Victory", 
        subtitle= "Understanding the Impact of Rebounding on the Liberty's Performance",
        caption="Source: Wehoop") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    ) +
  theme_minimal()









Okay, so the Liberty are dominating when it comes to rebounds, let’s look at another perspective. According to my third chart, the New York Liberty had more assists than any other team in the league… except the Minnesota Lynx. That’s huge. It means the Liberty are exceeding at at setting each other up and playing as a team, which helps them get better shots and more chances to score. While their three-point percentage might not be elite, the volume and quality of those shots are heavily supported by how well they move the ball. This unselfish, fast-paced style may actually be a real driving factor in their success.


Code
wnbadata <- load_wnba_team_box(2024) |> 
  filter(season_type == 2)

seasondata <- wnbadata |> 
  group_by(team_name) |> 
  summarize(
     total_assists = sum(assists),
    total_wins = sum(ifelse(team_winner == TRUE, 1, 0))
) 
  
libertydata <- seasondata |>
  filter(
    team_name == "Liberty"
)

seasondatalong <- seasondata |> 
  pivot_longer(
    cols = starts_with("total"),
    names_to = "Type",
    values_to = "Value"
  ) 
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data = seasondatalong, aes(x = team_name, weight = Value, fill = Type)
  ) + 
  coord_flip() +
   labs(x="Team", 
        y="Total Wins & Assists", title="Does ball movement lead to wins?", 
        subtitle= "The Liberty are a league leader in assists — and it’s paying off on the scoreboard.",
        caption="Source: Wehoop") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    ) +
  theme_minimal()









After analyzing the New York Liberty’s performance, it became clear that their success didn’t stem from their three-point shooting as I initially suspected. While their three-point shooting is barely above average, their dominance in other areas such as leading the league in rebounds and ranking second in assists, has been far more influential to their success. This analysis highlights how a well-rounded game, rather than relying on just one aspect like three-point shooting, is driving their success. Looking ahead, maintaining their rebounding percentage and assist efficiency will be crucial to sustaining their position at the top of the league in the upcoming season.
